definition:
A sequence $x_0, x_1, x_2, \dots$ in a metric space $(X,d)$ is a *Cauchy
sequence* if, for every real number $\epsilon > 0$, there exists a
natural number $N$ such that $d(x_n,x_m) < \epsilon$ whenever $n,m > N$.

Likewise, a sequence $v_0, v_1, v_2, \dots$ in a topological vector
space $V$ is a *Cauchy sequence* if and only if for every neighborhood
$U$ of $\mathbf{0}$, there exists a natural number $N$ such that
$v_n - v_m \in U$ for all $n,m > N$. These two definitions are
equivalent when the topology of $V$ is induced by a metric.
